column31: Automated water samplers mounted on the seafloor and surface sampling conducted from ships using discrete borosilicate bottles. Samples are preserved with HgCl2 for later determination of dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) and total alkalinity (TA). Measurements are typically restricted to reef flat environments, though plans are in place to expand to lagoonal and back reef habitats. Approximately 10-12 day deployment of automated water samplers at each deployment period; water samplers collect discrete water samples at 2 hour intervals. Meanwhile, surface samples are manually collected by boat along langrangian transects across the reef flat.

column33: At three unique cool and shallow volcanic CO2 seeps in Milne Bay Province, Papua New Guinea, we study the history of CO2 exposure and related rates of biotic calcification, and fluxes of DIC, on tropical coral reefs (Fabricius et al., 2011). The site is presently the only site known where pure and cool CO2, free of other toxic substances such as hydrogen sulfide or arsenic, emerges in shallow tropical coral reefs. The CO2 gas bubbles emerging from the reefs provide local ocean acidification conditions similar to those predicted for the middle to the end of this century, and beyond. We have completed four studies focusing on reef benthos and collecting seawater chemistry data. We found that some corals and other benthic coral reef organisms can acclimatize and adapt to a moderate increase in CO2, but that reefs will lose their structural complexity, diversity and will look profoundly different at high CO2 . No reef development was found below above a threshold of around 750 ppm CO2.

(2007). Certified reference materials are used to verify the measurement accuracy meets international guidelines of accuracy and precision better than ± 2 micromol/kg. While the measurement accuracy is better than ± 2 micromol/kg for samples returned to the laboratory, this does not guarantee the reported measurement accuracy is this good as sampling and storage problems can occassionally cause artefacts.; Temperature and salinity measurements were made using a seabird SBE19 CTD that is calibrated annually at a certified National Association of Testing Authorities Site facility at CSIRO, Hobart, Australia. Water samples are also collected with each cast and analysed using a Guideline austral and OSIL seawater standards to check the CTD derived salinity values.; Nutrients are analysed after Becker et al., (2018) GO-SHIP Repeat Hydrography Manual: Determination of Dissolved Nutrients (N, P, SI) in Seawater With High Precision and Inter-Comparability Using Gas-Segmented Continuous Flow Analysers,

column31: TA samples are collected in 250-mL glass amber bottles and poisoned with 50 µL of saturated HgCl2 solution, stored at 4°C and analyzed in the laboratory. For pH, seawater samples are analyzed on board ship within one hour of sample collection. Samples for pH are measured using the spectrophotometric method of Clayton and Byrne (1993) as modified by DelValls and Dickson (1998) and Dickson et al. (2007). TA analyses follows the method of Breland and Byrne (1993) and Yao and Byrne (1998), with modifications suggested by Dr. Wensheng Yao (personal communication). Further details on the alkalinity and pH methods can be found in Astor et al. (2005). The precision of the alkalinity and pH measurements are 4 µmol kg-1 and 0.003 units of pH, respectively. Certified alkalinity reference materials (CRM's) supplied by A. G. Dickson (Scripps Institute of Oceanography) are analyzed for TA with each batch of samples for each cruise. The standard deviation between the mean value of alkalinity measurements of the standards and the certified value is 2 µmol kg-1.

column31: The parameters we measured to characterize the various components of the carbonate system are pH and TA at 19 different depths. TA samples are collected in 250-mL glass amber bottles and poisoned with 50 ÂµL of saturated HgCl2 solution, stored at 4Â°C and analyzed in the laboratory. For pH, seawater samples are analyzed on board ship within one hour of sample collection. Samples for pH are measured using the spectrophotometric method of Clayton and Byrne (1993) as modified by DelValls and Dickson (1998) and Dickson et al. (2007). TA analyses follows the method of Breland and Byrne (1993) and Yao and Byrne (1998), with modifications suggested by Dr. Wensheng Yao (personal communication). Further details on the alkalinity and pH methods can be found in Astor et al. (2005).

column31:
System Assembly:
The system is comprised of of a stainless steel frame containing a spectrophotometric pH sensor, a SEA-BIRD Electronics 37 SMP ODO conductivity (and salinity), temperature and dissolved oxygen sensor and a battery housing containing batteries and the hub electronics. The ocean acidification kit also includes an Iridium satellite telemetry unit with a 25 m length cable.

Specifications:

Depth rating:
The systems depth rating is limited by the pressure tolerance of the battery housing which is 150 m, therefore the recommended deployment depth is less than 150 m. When the telemetry unit is used, the depth is limited to the length of the telemetry unit cable which is 25 m. 
Deployment duration:
The endurance of the system is limited by the battery capacity of the main system. Battery capacity was specified to allow hourly measurements over a period of one month. Theoretically, battery endurance will double at measurements every 2 hours or triple for measurements every 3 hours and so on. The spectrophotometric pH sensor uses meta-cresol purple pH indicator dye. The sensor is provided with 125 mL of the indicator which is expected to last more than 5 years at the rate of one (1) measurement per hour sampling frequency. The SEA-BIRD 37 sensor is powered by its own internal non-rechargeable battery pack. The battery endurance can be calculated using the SEA BIRD endurance calculator software. For hourly measurements the battery endurance is expected to last about 2 years.
Measurement frequency:
The measurement frequency can be adjusted from continuous (every 10 minutes) to 1 measurement every several hours. The telemetry unit is pre-adjusted to transmit the latest measurement every hour. This, however, can be reconfigured at a later stage (see modems manual).

column31: Hydrographic assessment involved measurements of temperature, salinity, oxygen, chlorophyll-a, seawater pH and total alkalinity conditions (Table 1). Sea surface temperature (SST), subsurface temperature (T10), salinity and dissolved oxygen vertical variations were assessed from above the bottom to the surface (? 30 m) through vertical CTD-O casts (SeaBird SBE19 Plus CTD equipped with a Wet Star oxygen sensor). For chlorophyll-a (Chl) (i.e. copepods food resources), pH and total alkalinity measurements, 30 L of seawater were obtained with a 10 L Niskin bottle at 10 m depth, because this depth tends to represent the mean habitat of the dominant neritic copepods in this area [38,70]. Size-fractioned Chl (> 20 and < 20 ?m) concentration was measured in triplicate with a TD Turner fluorometer after that 200 mL subsamples were sieved with a 20 ?m mesh sieve and filtered onto GF/F filter. After that, Chl was extracted in the dark for 24 h in 90% acetone v/v [Strickland & Parsons 1962). Seawater pH@25°C was measured within 1 h after sampling in a closed 25 mL cell thermostated using a Metrohm 827 pH meter (input resistance, > 1×1012 Ohm, 0.1 mV sensitivity and nominal resolution at 0.01 pH units) and a glass combined double junction Ag/AgCl electrode (Aquatrode PT1000, N/P 6.0257.000) calibrated with 4, 7 and 8 Tris buffer. Samples for total alkalinity analysis were collected in borosilicate glass bottles with ground glass stoppers (250 mL) and poisoned with 10 ?L HgCl2. Total alkalinity (AT) was determined using the open-cell titration method [Dickson et al. 2007], by mean of an automated Alkalinity Titrator AS-ALK2 Apollo SciTech. All samples were analyzed at 25º C (± 0.1º C) with thermal regulation using a water-bath. The accuracy for AT determinations was controlled against a certified reference material (A. Dickson, USA). Data of AT, T10, salinity, and pH@25°C were used to calculate in situ pH, PCO2 and others parameters of the carbonate marine system through the program CO2SYS version 01.05 [Pierrot et al. 2006]. Thus, in situ pH values were reported according to the National Bureau of Standards scale (pHNBS) (Guidelines for reporting ocean acidification data in scientific journals, Version 1.0, 2015-03-06).
